facts.text: Raja Prosanna Deb Raikat died intestate on December 4, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Prosanna Deb Raikat, the proprietor of the Baikundiapur Raj Estate, in the district of jalpaiguri in West Bengal, died intestate on December 4, 1946.

facts.text: Raja Prosanna Deb Raikat was proprietor of Baikundiapur Raj Estate in Jalpaiguri district, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Prosanna Deb Raikat, the proprietor of the Baikundiapur Raj Estate, in the district of jalpaiguri in West Bengal, died intestate on December 4, 1946.

facts.text: Raja left widow Rani Asrumati Debi and daughter Prativa Bose.

anchor.surface_text: The Raja left behind him a widow, Rani Asrumati Debi, number deceased and the appellant Prativa Bose, the daughter by her.

facts.text: Rani Asrumati Debi took possession of the estate after Raja's death.

anchor.surface_text: Rani Asrumati took possession of the estate on the Rajas death.

facts.text: Respondent Rupendra instituted suit on August 7, 1947 against Rani Asrumati and others claiming sole heir to impartible estate under primogeniture.

anchor.surface_text: On August 7, 1947, the respondent Rupendra instituted a suit in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of jalpaiguri, against Rani Asrumati and certain other agnatic relations of the, Raj for a declaration that as the Raja is eldest son by another wife Rani Renchi, he was the sole lawful heir and entitled to the exclusive possession of the estate which was an impartible estate and governed by the rule of pri- mogeniture, and for possession and other companysequential reliefs.

facts.text: Estate was impartible and governed by rule of primogeniture.

anchor.surface_text: ...entitled to the exclusive possession of the estate which was an impartible estate and governed by the rule of pri- mogeniture, and for possession and other companysequential reliefs.

facts.text: Rupendra alleged Raja married Rani Renchi (Lepcha tribe) according to Gandharba form.

anchor.surface_text: Rani Renchi was a lady belonging to the Lepcha tribe and the respondent Rupendra alleged that the Raja had married her according to the Gandharba form.

facts.text: Suit contested by Rani Asrumati denying marriage between Raja and Rupendra's mother.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by Rani Asrumati and the agnatic relations who denied that there had been any marriage between the Raja and the mother of the respondent Rupendra.

facts.text: Suit transferred to Calcutta High Court on April 12, 1949 under cl. 13 Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was transferred to the High Court at Calcutta by an order made on April 12, 1949 under cl. 13 of its Letters Patent.

facts.text: Rupendra's receiver application dismissed by High Court on July 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Rupendra made an application to the High Court in that suit for appointment of a receiver but it was dismissed on July 29, 1952.

facts.text: Two other suits filed by Kumar Guru Charan and Kumar Jitendra claiming sole heir, pending in Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that two agnatic relations, namely, Kumar Guru Charan and Kumar Jitendra filed suits in the High Court at Calcutta each claiming title to the estate as the sole heir of the deceased Raja. All these suits are still pending.

facts.text: Rani Asrumati died on January 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On January 5, 1954, Rani Asrumati died and thereupon the appellant Prativa Bose took possession of the estate claiming title to it.

facts.text: Prativa Bose took possession of estate after Rani Asrumati's death and remains in possession.

anchor.surface_text: On January 5, 1954, Rani Asrumati died and thereupon the appellant Prativa Bose took possession of the estate claiming title to it. Since then she has been and still is in possession.

facts.text: Rupendra filed application under s.4 Bengal Regulation V of 1799 on March 31, 1954 to District Judge Jalpaiguri for security from Prativa Bose.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1954, the respondent Rupendra filed an application under s. 4 of the Bengal Regulation V of. 1799 in the Court of the District Judge of jalpaiguri for an order calling upon the appellant Prativa Bose to furnish security for companypliance with the judgment that may be passed in the suit filed by him.

facts.text: District Judge dismissed application on grounds: s.4 not apply to single heir intestate case, and barred by Art.181 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District judge dismissed the application on two grounds. He first held that s. 4 of the Regulation did number apply to a case where a person died intestate leaving a single heir and the dispute was between several persons claiming to be that heir. Then he held that the application by the respondent Rupendra was barred under Art. 181 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act.

facts.text: High Court in revision set aside District Judge's order, directed to take security from Prativa Bose.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disagreed with the learned District Judge on both the points and set aside his order and directed him to exercise his special Jurisdiction under s. 4 of the Regulation and take sufficient security from the opposite party Prativa Bose.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave: Civil Appeal No. 539 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 539 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 6, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 499 of 1955.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated June 6, 1956 in Civil Rule No. 499 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 6, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 499 of 1955.

facts.text: Rupendra claims to be eldest son by Rani Renchi.

anchor.surface_text: ...as the Raja is eldest son by another wife Rani Renchi, he was the sole lawful heir...

facts.text: All title suits still pending.

anchor.surface_text: All these suits are still pending.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered May 10, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: May 10, 1963. The Judgment of M. Hidayatullah, Raghubar Dayal and N. Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ., was delivered by Raghubar Dayal J.

facts.text: District Judge of Jalpaiguri has jurisdiction under s.4 Regulation as Zila Court successor.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear, therefore, that the words Judge and Zila Courts in the Regulation have number to be understood as referring respectively to District Judges and District Courts appointed and companystituted under the Act of 1887.

facts.text: Receiver appeal records do not show success.

anchor.surface_text: There was an appeal from this order but the records do number show that it succeeded.

facts.text: Prativa Bose is appellant, Rupendra is respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is by Prativa Bose against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Bengal Regulation V of 1799 limits Zila Courts interference in intestate estates.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Bengal Regulation V of 1799 appears to have been to limit the interference of the Zila Courts of Diwani Adalat in the execution of wills and administration to the estate of persons dying intestate.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 6, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 499 of 1955.

On March 31, 1954, the respondent Rupendra filed an application under s. 4 of the Bengal Regulation V of. 1799 in the Court of the District Judge of jalpaiguri for an order calling upon the appellant Prativa Bose to furnish security for compliance with the judgment that may be passed in the suit filed by him.

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up the question of limitation. It does number seem to us that the question really arises. Article 181 of the Limitation Act, 19.08, prescribes the time within which certain applications can be made. Section 4, however, does number require any application before an order calling upon a person to furnish security can be made under it.

issues.text: whether the order could only be made by the court where the suit mentioned in s. 4 of the Regulation was pending

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the order could only be made by the court where the suit mentioned in s. 4 of the Regulation was pending. The High Court at Calcutta held in Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb 1  that the order could be made by a District Judge even though the suit mentioned was number pending before him.

issues.text: the question concerning the correct interpretation of s. 4 of the Regulation

holdings.text: Article 181 of the Limitation Act does not apply to proceedings under s.4 of Bengal Regulation V of 1799 as no application is required and the court acts suo motu.

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up the question of limitation. It does not seem to us that the question really arises. Article 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908, prescribes the time within which certain applications can be made. Section 4, however, does not require any application before an order calling upon a person to furnish security can be made under it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 does not mention application; intended suo motu; Regulation predates Limitation Act; precedents confirm no limitation where no application needed.

holdings.text: Even if application required under s.4, Art.181 applies only to applications under CPC by ejusdem generis.

anchor.surface_text: Article 181 would have no operation where no application is required to enable a court to make an order see The Oriental Bank Corporation v. J. A. Charriol and Sohan v. Khalak Singh. The present case cannot, therefore, be decided on the ground that the application by the respondent Rupendra had been made beyond the time prescribed by Art. 181.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial gloss adds 'under the Code' to Art.181; amendments to other articles do not alter; s.141 CPC applies procedure only, not substance.

holdings.text: District Judge (successor to Zila Court Judge) has jurisdiction under s.4 even if suit pending elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the order could only be made by the court where the suit mentioned in s. 4 of the Regulation was pending. The High Court at Calcutta held in Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb that the order could be made by a District Judge even though the suit mentioned was not pending before him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Judge' means District Judge per historical succession; s.23 Civil Courts Act requires HC order for subordinate judges.

holdings.text: s.4 applies where right of succession disputed between claimants each claiming to be the single heir.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the words if the right of succession to the estate be disputed between several claimants, taken by themselves, clearly include a case where a person dies leaving a single heir and several persons dispute each claiming to be that heir.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain meaning post-semicolon; plural includes singular; no rule semicolon subordinates clauses; s.3 and s.4 both applicable without conflict.

holdings.text: Under s.4, District Judge has discretion, not obligation, to demand security considering circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We think the section leaves it to the District Judge to ask for security if in all the circumstances of the case he thinks that is the proper order to make. He has a discretion in the matter and is not obliged as soon as a case comes under the section, to demand the security.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual: suo motu hard without knowledge; policy restricts interference; ss.4-5 stages discretionary (may, authorised); absurdity otherwise.

holdings.text: High Court justified in revision as Dist Judge erroneously refused jurisdiction under s.4.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, fully justified in setting aside the order of the learned District Judge in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous refusal of vested jurisdiction triggers CPC s.115 revision per precedent.

holdings.text: ss.192-195 Indian Succession Act 1925 do not impliedly repeal s.4 Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: Then it was said that ss. 192-195 of the Succession Act, 1925 impliedly repealed s. 4 of the Regulation. These sections of the Succession Act no doubt deal with a summary decision of a disputed right to possession on Succession. But they are not identical with s. 4 of Regulation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not identical; Succession Act applies sans suit, allows dispossession; no conflict hence no repeal.

holdings.text: s.4 of Regulation V 1799 second part does not apply to single heir intestate cases covered by s.III.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the second part of s. IV does not apply to the case where the deceased dies intestate leaving only one heir entitled to succeed to the entire estate...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.III complete code for single heir; s.IV for multiple heirs; 'but' makes exception to first part of s.IV; historical purpose restricts interference; harmonious construction.

precedents.case_name: The Oriental Bank Corporation v. J. A. Charriol
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 181 of Limitation Act has no operation where no application is required to enable court to make an order

anchor.surface_text: Sohan v. Khalak Singh  2 The present case cannot, therefore, be decided on the ground that the application by the respondent Rupendra had been made beyond the time prescribed by Art. 181.

precedents.cited_proposition: Article 181 of Limitation Act has no operation where no application is required to enable court to make an order

precedents.citation: She Mulchand C, o. Ltd. V. Jawahar Mills Ltd  1

anchor.surface_text: She Mulchand C, o. Ltd. V. Jawahar Mills Ltd  1  puts the matter correctly. The learned judge said, It does not appear to us quite convincing without further argument, that the mere amendment of articles 158 and 178 can ipso facto alter the meaning which, as a result of a long series of Judicial decisions of the different High Courts in India, came to be attached to the language used in article 181.

precedents.case_name: She Mulchand & Co Ltd v Jawahar Mills Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 181 is confined to applications under the Code of Civil Procedure even after 1948 amendments to other articles
precedents.cited_holding: The mere amendment of articles 158 and 178 cannot alter the meaning attached to Article 181 by long series of judicial decisions

precedents.citation: Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb 1

anchor.surface_text: Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb 1  that the order could be made by a District Judge even though the suit mentioned was not pending before him. We think that this is the correct view.

precedents.case_name: Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb
precedents.cited_proposition: District Judge can make order under s.4 of Regulation even if the suit is not pending before him

precedents.citation: Joy Chand Cal Babel v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 1

anchor.surface_text: Joy Chand Cal Babel v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury 1 . This principle fully applies to the present case. the trial Court erroneously held-that is erroneously in the view of the High Court a view with which we agree- that properly interpreted s. 4 did not apply to the present case,

precedents.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v Kamalaksha Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Erroneous decision resulting in subordinate court failing to exercise jurisdiction vested in it gives rise to revisional jurisdiction

precedents.citation: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava  .

anchor.surface_text: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava  . We think the context in the present case does so. It certainly does seem to us very strange that a person in possession of property claiming to be an heir should be required by a statute to give security merely because some other person claims to be entitled to it as the heir,

precedents.case_name: State of U.P. v Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents.cited_proposition: Context may indicate a different intention from the prima facie obligatory meaning of 'shall'

anchor.surface_text: Cohen v. E. Railway.  . To appreciate the contention for the appellant, it is necessary to consider the entire object of making the Regulation. The title of the Regulation states A Regulation to limit the interference of the Zillah and City Courts of Dewanny Adawlut in the execution of wills and administration to the estates of persons dying intestate.

precedents.cited_proposition: Words following a semicolon or in separate clause not necessarily limited to preceding subject matter

anchor.surface_text: Cohen v. S.E. Railway 1  are not of much help in order to construe the scope of the second part of s. IV in regard to its applicability to cases coming under s. III. Those observations were made in a different context about the provisions of the Acts there under consideration.

precedents.cited_proposition: No rule that clause at end of section is confined to subject matter of previous parts of the section

anchor.surface_text: Cohens Case 1  to the construction of the second part of s. IV with respect to its applicability to s. III. We do not find the provisions of III and s. IV to be inconsistent in any manner and to necessitate their being construed together.

precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions should be construed to harmonize if inconsistent

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up the question of limitation. It does not seem to us that the question really arises. Article 181 of the Limitation Act, 1908, prescribes the time within which certain applications can be made. Section 4, however, does not require any application before an order calling upon a person to furnish security can be made under it.

We, therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Court below and dismiss the application of the respondents presented to the District judge under s. IV of Regulation V of 1799. We order that the respondents will pay the costs of the

anchor.surface_text: Article 181 would have no operation where no application is required to enable a court to make an order see The Oriental Bank Corporation v. J. A. Charriol and Sohan v. Khalak Singh. The present case cannot, therefore, be decided on the ground that the application by the respondent Rupendra had been made beyond the time prescribed by Art. 181.

We, therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Court below and dismiss the application of the respondents presented to the District judge under s. IV of Regulation V of 1799. We order that the respondents will pay the costs of the

edges.explanation: Holding h3 overlaps textually with issue i2 and directly resolves the jurisdictional question of whether the order under s.4 could only be made by the court where the suit was pending by affirming District Judge jurisdiction even if suit pending elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the order could only be made by the court where the suit mentioned in s. 4 of the Regulation was pending. The High Court at Calcutta held in Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb that the order could be made by a District Judge even though the suit mentioned was not pending before him.

We, therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Court below and dismiss the application of the respondents presented to the District judge under s. IV of Regulation V of 1799. We order that the respondents will pay the costs of the

anchor.surface_text: We think the section leaves it to the District Judge to ask for security if in all the circumstances of the case he thinks that is the proper order to make. He has a discretion in the matter and is not obliged as soon as a case comes under the section, to demand the security.

anchor.surface_text: Then it was said that ss. 192-195 of the Succession Act, 1925 impliedly repealed s. 4 of the Regulation.
